channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Harvard's Steven Levitsky says Trump administration acts as authoritarian government
item.description: Steven Levitsky is director of the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American studies at Harvard and researches authoritarian governments. He talks with NPR about Trump's attacks on universities.

item.title: NPR listeners share their memories of loved ones who died serving in the military
item.description: On this Memorial Day, NPR Morning Edition listeners share memories of loved ones who died while serving in the military.

item.title: Russia launches massive drone and missile assaults on Ukrainian cities
item.description: Russia intensified strikes on Ukraine over the last three nights, even as the two countries carried out the largest prisoner swap since Russia's full-scale invasion began more than three years ago.

item.title: Israeli airstrike kills 9 of Gaza pediatrician's children
item.description: Israeli airstrikes on Gaza have killed hundreds in the past week, including nine children of a pediatrician while she was at work. Israel's military says the attack is under review.

item.title: Using an app to rate food for nutrition? Take the results with a grain of salt
item.description: Food apps can help you figure out what's in your food and whether it's nutritious. Just scan the barcode on the packet with your phone. But different apps can give very different results. Here's why.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Russia intensifies strikes on Ukraine, summer travel season gets underway in the U.S., federal government forecasts above-normal fire potential in much of the West and some southeastern states.

item.title: Author Jonathan Horn discusses his new book, 'The Fate of the Generals'
item.description: NPR speaks with Jonathan Horn about his new book, "The Fate of the Generals," which tells the story of two commanders in World War II who received the same medal but found honor on different paths.

item.title: U.S. sheep industry cautiously optimistic over Trump's tariffs
item.description: Many in agriculture are worried that Trump administration tariffs will be bad for their bottom lines. The American sheep industry, though, is cautiously optimistic.

item.title: Florida ends program that allowed some immigrant students to pay in-state tuition
item.description: Florida has eliminated a program that allowed immigrant students under DACA protections to pay in-state tuition. Now, thousands have to figure out how to finish college with higher costs.

item.title: Inside a Louisiana factory making torpedo bats that have become all the rage
item.description: Torpedo baseball bats hit it big when the Yankees set a new team record with nine home runs in one game earlier this season. We visit a factory in Louisiana to see what makes them so special.
